    Discovery of Novel Fungal Lanosterol 14α-Demethylase (CYP51)/Histone Deacetylase Dual Inhibitors to Treat Azole-Resistant Candidiasis

    • Guiyan Han
      Guiyan Han
      Department of Medicinal Chemistry, School of Pharmacy, Second Military Medical University, 325 Guohe Road, Shanghai 200433, China
      More by Guiyan Han
      • ,

    SUBJECTS:

    • Antifungal activity
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Invasive fungal infections (particularly candidiasis) are emerging as severe infectious diseases worldwide. Because of serious antifungal drug resistance, therapeutic efficacy of the current treatment for candidiasis is limited and associated with high mortality. However, it is highly challenging to develop novel strategies and effective therapeutic agents to combat drug resistance. Herein, the first generation of lanosterol 14α-demethylase (CYP51)-histone deacetylase (HDAC) dual inhibitors was designed, which exhibited potent antifungal activity against azole-resistant clinical isolates. In particular, compounds 12h and 15j were highly active both in vitro and in vivo to treat azole-resistant candidiasis. Antifungal mechanism studies revealed that they acted by blocking ergosterol biosynthesis and HDAC catalytic activity in fungus, suppressing the function of efflux pump, yeast-to-hypha morphological transition, and biofilm formation. Therefore, CYP51-HDAC dual inhibitors represent a promising strategy to develop novel antifungal agents against azole-resistant candidiasis.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Invasive fungal infections (IFIs) are emerging as severe infectious diseases worldwide, mainly because of the increasing number of immunocompromised people.(1,2) Patients undergoing organ transplantations, clinical treatments in intensive care units (ICUs), and immunosuppressive and chemotherapeutic therapies and infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) are highly vulnerable to IFIs.(3,4) It is reported that about 300 fungal pathogens could cause human infections, among which Candida species are responsible for the most important pathogenic factors of IFI cases and cause over 400,000 life-threatening infections per year worldwide with a mortality of 46–75%.(5−8) Traditional antifungal agents including polyenes, azoles, echinocandins, and flucytosine have been widely used for the treatment of invasive candidiasis (IC), leading to severe drug resistance (particularly azole-resistance), reduced antifungal efficacy, and high mortal rate.(9−12) Therefore, the development of new antifungal agents against azole-resistant IC is highly desirable and challenging.(10,13)
    Lanosterol 14α-demethylase (CYP51) is the target of azole antifungal agents (Figure 1A), such as fluconazole (FLC), itraconazole (ITC), and voriconazole (VOR). Azoles block the biosynthesis of ergosterol in fungal cell membranes through inhibiting CYP51 and exert fungistatic activity.(11) The main molecular mechanisms of azole resistance include the overexpression of CYP51, mutations in the CYP51 structure, upregulation of efflux pumps, and formation of fungal biofilm.(3,4,14) Histone deacetylases (HDACs), a family of epigenetic enzymes, widely exist in eukaryocytes. By removing acetyl groups from histones and other proteins, HDACs play an important role in gene regulation, transcription, and posttranscriptional modification, which has been extensively investigated as antitumor targets.(15−17) Recently, fungal HDACs were found to play a key role in the development of drug resistance including azoles.(18−20) In addition, several fungal biological features and virulence are functionally influenced by HDACs.(21−23)
    The potential applications of HDAC inhibitors in the antifungal therapy have been preliminarily confirmed.(15,24,25) For example, HDAC inhibitors vorinostat (SAHA) and trichostatin A were reported to possess synergistic effects with FLC against azole-resistant fungi.(19,26) These findings provide a basis for the design of multitargeting agents to combat with severe azole resistance. Moreover, in vivo antifungal potencies and antifungal mechanism of action of the azole/HDAC inhibitor combination still remain to be explored.
    A multitargeting molecule may have the advantages of the synergistic effect and antiresistant efficacy, which also may be limited by a higher molecular weight, potential host toxicity of hitting multiple mechanisms.(27,28) Thus it is highly challenging to design a multitargeting molecule with desired druglike profiles. Previously, we designed Janus kinase 2 (JAK2)/HDAC dual inhibitors that could simultaneously treat leukemia and IFIs.(16) JAK2/HDAC dual inhibitors synergized with FLC both in vitro and in vivo to treat resistant fungal infections. Inspired by these results, we envisioned that direct antifungal activity against resistant IFIs could be achieved by the design of CYP51/HDAC dual inhibitors. Herein, the first generation of CYP51/HDAC dual inhibitors was designed to treat azole-resistant candidiasis. Compared with azole antifungal agents, the dual inhibitors revealed potent inhibitory activities against azole-resistant Candida species. Particularly, compounds 12h and 15j exhibited excellent in vitro and in vivo antifungal activity to treat resistant IC, whose antifungal and anti-resistant mechanisms were preliminarily clarified.

    Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Design of CYP51/HDAC Dual Inhibitors

    Previously, we have performed a systemic structure-based design and structure–activity relationship (SAR) studies of azole CYP51 inhibitors(29−37) and also designed a series of HDAC-based multitargeting inhibitors,(16,17,38−40) providing a basis for the rational design of CYP51/HDAC dual inhibitors. Herein, the CYP51/HDAC dual inhibitors were designed by merging the key pharmacophores of CYP51 and HDAC inhibitors. Generally, the classical HDAC inhibitor (e.g., SAHA) includes a surface recognition cap (SRC) group, a linker, and a zinc-binding group (ZBG, such as hydroxamic acid). A linker with a certain length and ZBG are known as the key pharmacophores of HDAC inhibitors, while diverse scaffolds can be designed as SRC groups.(41,42) The key pharmacophores of typical CYP51 inhibitors consist of a triazole ring (coordination with heme iron atom of CYP51) and difluorophenyl (or dichlorophenyl) ring (interaction with the hydrophobic pocket of CYP51), while diverse side chains with different lengths could be accommodated in the active site of CYP51.(29,43) Recently, the crystal structure of Candida albicans CYP51 in complex with posaconazole was solved (Figure 1B).(44) The binding mode of posaconazole indicates that the length of azoles generally correlates well with CYP51 inhibitory activity, and longer side chains can form additional interactions with the substrate access channel in CYP51. On the basis of the above analysis, the type A CYP51/HDAC dual inhibitors was designed by introducing a linker and hydroxamic acid ZBG on the structure of FLC (compounds 7a–c and 8a–c). Then, diverse N-methylbenzylamine containing linkers were investigated (types B and C) based on our previous experience in the design of CYP51 inhibitors (Figure 1C).(29) To validate the design rationale, compound 15j was selected to be docked into the active site of CYP51. The results revealed that it shared a similar binding mode with posaconazole with the ZBG and linker group inserted into the channel of CYP51 (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information).

    Chemistry

    The synthesis of the target compounds 7a–c, 8a–c, 12a–j, and 15a–t are depicted in Schemes 1–3, and the target compounds were obtained as racemates according to the optical rotation. Starting materials 1a, 1b, and 9a–f are commercially available, while starting materials 9g–j, 13a–q, oxirane 4, and intermediate 10 were synthesized according to the reported procedure.(37,45−50)
    Substitution of phenols 1a and 1b by brominated compounds gave nitriles 2a–c, followed by the addition of the cyano group with CH3OH in the acidic condition, and on further cyclization with formylhydrazine in the presence of trimethylamine (Et3N), intermediates 3a–c were obtained. Then, oxirane 4 was treated with intermediates 3a–c in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) using K2CO3 as the base to give intermediates 5a–c and 6a–c. Because intermediates 5a–c and 6a–c are structurally similar, their structures were further confirmed by 2D-NMR (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Finally, they were treated with freshly prepared hydroxylamine in basic CH3OH to afford target compounds 7a–c and 8a–c, respectively (Scheme 1).
    Target compounds 12a–j were synthesized using compounds 9a–j as the starting materials (Scheme 2). Briefly, compounds 9a–j were nucleophilic-substituted by intermediate 10 in the presence of K2CO3 to give intermediates 11a–j. Then, further deprotection of intermediates 11a–j in the presence of trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), followed by ring opening of oxirane 4 and the direct treatment with freshly prepared hydroxylamine in basic CH3OH afforded target compounds 12a–j.
    Target compounds 15a–t were synthesized according to the procedures outlined in Scheme 3. Starting from a reductive amination of aldehydes 13a–q in the presence of primary amine and sodium borohydride, intermediates 14a–t were obtained, which further reacted with oxirane 4 by the ring opening reaction and treated with freshly prepared hydroxylamine in basic CH3OH to afford target compounds 15a–t.

    In Vitro Antifungal Activities and SAR

    Initially, the in vitro antifungal activities of target compounds were evaluated using the CLSI (M27-A3) microdilution method(51) because the assays for evaluating fungal CYP51 and HDAC inhibitors are rather limited. Then, highly potent antifungal compounds will be selected for validation and investigation of the mechanism of action. Azole-sensitive C. albicans and Cryptococcus neoformans and four azole-resistant C. albicans and Candida tropicalis clinical isolates were used in the assay. The antifungal activities are expressed as MIC80 (the minimum inhibitory concentration with inhibition over 80%) values and azole antifungal agents FLC, ITC, VOR, and HDAC inhibitor SAHA were used as the positive drugs.
    Initially, linkers and ZBG were attached directly to FLC (compounds 7a–c and 8a–c, type A inhibitors). As shown in Table 1, most of the target compounds exhibited weak to moderate activities to both azole-sensitive and azole-resistant C. albicans (MIC80 range: 8–64 μg/mL). In contrast, FLC, ITC, VOR, and SAHA were inactive against azole-resistant strains. The results preliminarily validated the anti-resistance profiles of the designed compounds.
    Table 1. In Vitro Antifungal Activities of Compounds 7a–c and 8a–c (MIC80, μg/mL)
       Azole-sensitive C. alb.aAzole-resistant C. alb.aAzole-resistant C. tro.aAzole-sensitive C. neo.a
    Compd.mnSC53140304103778141085008H99
    7a308648326464
    7b3132328>646432
    7c404>6464>64>6464
    8a306432864>6464
    8b3183216>64>6464
    8c403232>64>64>6464
    FLCa  0.5>64>64>64>642
    ITCa  0.5>64>64>64>640.125
    VORa  0.125>64>64>64>640.0625
    SAHA  >64>64>64>64>64>64
    a

    Abbreviations: C. alb., Candida albicans; C. tro., Candida tropicalis; C. neo., Cryptococcus neoformans; FLC, fluconazole; ITC, itraconazole and VOR, voriconazole.

    To improve the antifungal activities, type B inhibitors featured as the N-methylaminomethylphenyltriazolone linker were designed and assayed (compounds 12a–j, Table 2). Compounds 12a–e with an alkyl linker (from 3 to 7 carbon atoms) generally showed moderate antifungal activity. When the linker was extended to 8 carbon atoms (compound 12f), antifungal activity was obviously improved. Further incorporation of the phenyl group into the alkyl linker (compounds 12g and 12h) led to a slight increase of the inhibitory activity against azole-resistant isolates. The introduction of the oxygen atom into the alkyl linker (compounds 12i and 12j) had little impact on the antifungal activity.
    Table 2. In Vitro Antifungal Activities of Compounds 12a–j (MIC80, μg/mL)
    To further explore the importance of the triazolone group for the antifungal activities, type C inhibitors were designed by removing the triazolone group and variation of N-substitutions and the linking site of the phenyl group (compounds 15a–t, Table 3). Interestingly, removing the triazolone group resulted in the improvement of the antifungal activity (compounds 15a–f). In particular, compounds 15d, 15e, and 15f showed excellent antifungal activities against both azole-sensitive and resistant fungal pathogens (MIC80 range: 0.125–1 μg/mL). The replacement of the linker oxygen atom by the amide (compounds 15g and 15h) led to decreased antifungal activity. In contrast, the introduction of an additional oxygen atom into the linker of compound 15f was favorable for the antifungal activity. Compound 15j showed potent inhibitory activity against azole-sensitive C. albicans (MIC80 = 0.125 μg/mL) and C. neoformans (MIC80 = 0.5 μg/mL). Importantly, it was still highly active against four azole-resistant clinical isolates with MIC80 values in the range of 0.25–0.5 μg/mL, whereas FLC, ITC, VOR, and SAHA were totally inactive. Furthermore, compound 15j was investigated by time-kill curve assays, which exhibited fungistatic activity against azole-resistant C. albicans at 16 μg/mL (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information).
    Table 3. In Vitro Antifungal Activities of Compounds 15a–t (MIC80, μg/mL)
    On the basis of compound 15j, the extension of a carbon atom between the phenyl group and hydroxamic acid (compound 15k) had negative effects on the antifungal activity. The meta (compounds 15i–n) or ortho (compounds 15o–q) substitution of the linker on the phenyl group also led to obvious decrease of the antifungal activity. Finally, when the N-methyl group of compound 15j was replaced by ethyl (15r), isopropyl (15s), or cyclopropyl (15t), significant decrease of the antifungal activity was observed.
    Among the target compounds, compounds 12h (type B inhibitors) and 15j (type C inhibitors) were chosen for further biological evaluations and mechanism studies on the basis of structural diversity and inhibitory activities against azole-resistant fungi. Initially, in vitro cytotoxicity of compounds 12h and 15j were assayed. They exhibited relatively weak cytotoxicity against human cell lines A549 (human lung carinoma cell line) and HUVEC (human umbilical vein endothelial cell line) with the IC50 values in the range of 3.9–16.1 μg/mL (6.7–25.4 μM), which were about 2–16 times higher than the MIC80 values against azole-resistant fungi (Table S1 in the Supporting Information).

    Compounds 12h and 15j Inhibited Biosynthesis of Ergosterol in Azole-Resistant C. albicans

    Ergosterol, a predominant sterol of fungal cell membranes, plays an important role in maintaining the stability and function of cell membranes. Azoles inhibit fungal CYP51 and block the production of ergosterol, which cause the accumulation of other sterols such as lanosterol, eburicol, and obtusifoliol, and then cause damage of fungal cell membranes and exert fungistatic activity.(52) Fungal CYP51s are membrane-bound proteins, which are difficult to be purified for biological assays.(53) As an alternative, the analysis of sterol composition of fungal cell membranes has been widely used to evaluate the activity of CYP51 inhibitors.(54−56) Therefore, the influences of compounds 12h (0.5 μg/mL) and 15j (0.5 μg/mL) on the sterol composition of azole-resistant C. albicans were explored by gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) with FLC (0.5 μg/mL) as the positive control (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information). The sterol profiling of the FLC group revealed that ergosterol was still the main sterol of the C. albicans cell membrane (74.97%), which was similar to that of the negative control group without the drug treatment. The results indicated that FLC was inactive against resistant C. albicans isolates possibly because of the poor inhibition of CYP51 and low damage to the cell membrane. In contrast, after the treatment of compounds 12h and 15j, the relative amount of ergosterol was decreased to 61.48 and 18.44%, respectively. Moreover, the amounts of lanosterol in these two groups were higher than the negative control group and FLC-treated group, suggesting that compounds 12h and 15j effectively blocked the demethylation of lanosterol (Table 4).The results were also consistent well with the MIC80 values, which indirectly indicated that compounds 12h and 15j could significantly inhibit CYP51 in resistant C. albicans cells.
    Table 4. Sterol Composition Analysis of C. albicans 0304103 Cells Treated by Compounds 12h, 15j, and FLC
      sterol composition (%)
    sterolretention time (min)no drugFLC12h15j
    unknown sterol (1)13.822.913.06  
    ergosterol14.0675.2174.9761.4818.44
    unknown sterol (2)14.506.777.5  
    unknown sterol (3)14.964.784.7  
    obtusifoliol15.12   7.59
    unknown sterol (4)15.261.291.17  
    lanosterol15.784.153.9425.298.57
    unknown sterol (5)15.904.874.66  
    eburicol16.68  13.2265.4

    Compounds 12h and 15j Inhibited Fungal HDACs

    Until date, the assay for determining inhibitory activity against fungal HDAC is still rare. Herein, we developed a whole fungal cell HDAC enzymatic assay to test whether compounds 12h and 15j were fungal HDAC inhibitors. Briefly, the protoplasts of C. albicans were prepared using snailase. Then, the protoplasts were treated with different concentrations of compounds 12h, 15j, SAHA and FLC, and the HDAC substrate was added subsequently. Finally, the fluorescence intensity deriving from the decomposition of the HDAC substrate in different groups was monitored to evaluate the inhibitory activities of fungal HDACs (Table 5). The results revealed that compounds 12h and 15j could inhibit the activities of whole fungal cell HDAC with an IC50 value of 1.3 and 0.16 μM, respectively, while SAHA exhibited weaker inhibition activity (IC50 = 1.5 μM) and FLC was totally inactive. In contrast, compounds 12h and 15j exhibited relatively weaker inhibitory activity against whole human cell HDACs with an IC50 value of 6.8 and 2.7 μM, respectively, whereas SAHA inhibited whole human cell HDACs more strongly than compounds 12h and 15j. Similarly, compounds 12h and 15j all inhibit HDAC1 and HDAC6 with weaker activity than SAHA.
    Table 5. HDAC Enzyme Inhibition Activities (IC50, μM)
    compoundswhole fungal cell HDACwhole human cell HDACHDAC1HDAC6
    12h1.36.80.280.12
    15j0.162.70.690.60
    SAHA1.50.850.0560.024
    FLC>40>40  

    Compounds 12h and 15j Inhibited Azole-Resistant C. albicans by Downregulating the Expression of CYP51 and Efflux Pump Related Genes

    It was widely accepted that one of the most important mechanisms of azole resistance in C. albicans is mutation or increase of CYP51 (encoded by ERG11), causing the reduced affinity of azoles to CYP51.(9) In addition, the upregulation of efflux pump and increased efflux of drugs from cells is another ubiquitous mechanism of azole resistance. A number of genes were associated with fungal efflux pump, such as CDR1, CDR2, MDR1, and so forth.(57,58) In order to better understand the antiresistant mechanism of compounds 12h and 15j in C. albicans cells, the relative expression levels of four resistance related genes (i.e., ERG11, CDR1, CDR2, and MDR1) were investigated using real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) (Figure 2A) using FLC as the control. It could be observed that the expression of four genes was increased significantly under the stimulation of FLC, which might be the important reason for the obvious resistance of C. albicans 0304103 to FLC. Interestingly, decrease or even reversal of the gene expression was observed after the treatment of dual CYP51/HDAC inhibitors as compared to the FLC group. Compound 12h led to significant decrease on the expression levels of ERG11, CDR1, and CDR2, while compound 15j resulted in the downregulation of ERG11, CDR1, CDR2, and MDR1 genes.
    To further investigate the effects of compounds 12h and 15j on the efflux pump of azole-resistant C. albicans, rhodamine 6G (Rh6G) efflux assay was performed. Fluorescent Rh6G, a substrate of the efflux pump, can be pumped by the efflux pump outside the fungal cells after being preloaded into cells.(59) The effects of compounds 12h and 15j on Rh6G efflux were evaluated by measuring the extracellular fluorescence intensity of Rh6G at different designated time points (Figure 2B). The results indicated that the efflux of Rh6G in the FLC group was obviously higher than that in compounds 12h and 15j treated groups, which were consistent to the fact that FLC increased higher expression of the efflux pump than compounds 12h and 15j. Moreover, the decreased expression of CYP51 and efflux pump-related genes might be caused by HDAC inhibition.

    Compounds 12h and 15j Inhibited Yeast-to-Hypha Morphological Transition and Biofilm Formation

    Morphogenetic transitions between yeast and hyphae are prevalent for fungi, which is the key virulence for pathogenic fungi including Candida species.(60) Hyphal forms of fungi provide a stronger ability of invasion and adhesion to the hosts than the yeast form.(61) The fungal biofilm is a highly structured and specific community where fungal cells are surrounded by a self-produced extracellular polymeric substance, which makes it difficult for antifungal agents to reach the cells, and related resistance is developed.(62) Meanwhile, filamentation is also an important factor of the formation of the mature biofilm. Therefore, the influences of compounds 12h and 15j on the yeast-to-hypha morphogenetic transitions of C. albicans were evaluated using the differential interference contrast (DIC) microscope with FLC as the positive drug. Compounds 12h (8 μg/mL) and 15j (1 μg/mL) completely inhibited the formation of hyphae. In contrast, FLC (up to 32 μg/mL) had no obvious effect on filamentation of C. albicans (Figure 3A). The inhibitory activity of compounds 12h and 15j against biofilms of C. albicans were evaluated by the 2,3-bis(2-methoxy-4-nitro-5-sulfophenyl)-2H-tetrazolium-5-carboxanilide (XTT) reduction assay with FLC as the positive drug. The results revealed that compounds 12h and 15j effectively and dose-dependently inhibited biofilm formation of C. albicans. In contrast, only 22.9% of biofilm inhibition of FLC was achieved at the high concentration (64 μg/mL). Thus, compounds 12h and 15j were significantly more active than FLC in inhibiting biofilm formation (Figure 3B).
    To further clarify the mechanism of inhibiting yeast-to-hypha morphological transition and biofilm formation, real-time RT-PCR was performed to investigate the effects of compounds 12h and 15j on the expression of several hyphae and biofilm-associated genes. EFG1, TEC1, and CPH1 encode transcription factors, which are involved in the hyphal growth and further biofilm formation.(63−65)ALS3 encodes cell wall adhesin and participates in the biofilm formation.(66) As shown in Figure 3C, the four genes were downregulated after the treatment of compounds 12h and 15j. The results were well consistent with the fact that compounds 12h and 15j inhibited yeast-to-hypha morphological transition and biofilm formation.

    Compounds 12h and 15j Displayed Potent In Vivo Antifungal Effects

    IC, particularly azole-resistant candidiasis, is associated with high mortality.(67) For the resistant C. albicans strains, the efficacy of azole antifungal agents is generally rather limited.(68) Thus, the in vivo antifungal efficacies of compounds 12h and 15j were evaluated using the IC murine model infected with clinical azole-resistant C. albicans isolates. The murine model was established by injection with azole-resistant C. albicansvia the lateral tail vein with cyclophosphamide as the immunosuppressant. Mice were assigned into six groups, which were treated by saline, compound 12h (20 mg/kg), and compound 15j (20 mg/kg) by intraperitoneal (IP) administration or oral (PO) administration. The treatment was performed for five days. Then, the mice were euthanized, and their kidneys were dissected, in which the left kidney was homogenized to evaluate the renal fungal burden. As shown in Figure 4A, the kidney fungal burden could be significantly reduced by the IP injection of compounds 12h and 15j at the dose of 20 mg/kg, whose log10 cfu/g value was decreased from 6.89 to 4.49 (P < 0.001) and to 6.16 (P < 0.001), respectively. Similarly, significant decrease of kidney fungal burden was observed for compounds 12h and 15j after oral administration. Generally, compound 12h showed better efficacy by IP injection than PO administration, whereas compound 15j exhibited no significant difference in the two administration ways. Among these groups, compound 12h by IP administration showed the best in vivo antifungal effects.
    The right kidneys of the selected mice in each group were stained using periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) for histological studies. Evident infections were observed with abundant colonization of fungal cells, aggregation of inflammatory leukocytes and cavitation of kidney tissues for the saline group (Figure 4B). After the treatment of compound 12h or 15j, the degree of infections was obviously alleviated. Consistently, therapeutic efficacy of the IP administration group was superior to that of the PO administration group. Additionally, in the saline group, C. albicans were mainly observed in the form of hyphae. In contrast, they predominantly exhibited the form of yeast in the compound-treated groups. The results were in good accordance with their in vitro inhibition of filamentation.
    On the basis of the in vivo results, compounds 12h (20 mg/kg, IP) and 15j (20 mg/kg, IP) were further evaluated for the efficacy to extend the survival time of the infected mice. In the saline group, the median survival time (MST) was 10 days (Figure 4C). After the treatment of compound 12h or 15j, a prolonged survival time were observed with MST significantly increased to 20 and 16.5 days, respectively.

    Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    In summary, we designed and synthesized the first fungal CYP51/HDAC dual inhibitors for the treatment of azole-resistant Candida species. Most of them exhibited potent inhibitory activities against resistant fungi in vitro. In particular, compounds 12h and 15j were highly potent to treat resistant IC both in vitro and in vivo. It was observed that they were able to significantly decrease the renal fungal burden and prolong survival time in the azole-resistant IC murine models. The mechanism studies revealed that compounds 12h and 15j possessed antifungal activities by suppressing biosynthesis of ergosterol (CYP51 inhibition) and exerted anti-resistant profiles by downregulating the expression of CYP51 and the efflux pump (HDAC inhibition). Taken together, this proof-of-concept study provided an effective strategy to treat azole-resistant candidiasis. Further investigation of the antifungal mechanisms and structural optimization of the dual CYP51/HDAC inhibitors are currently in progress.

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry

    General Methods

    Column chromatography was carried out on 300–400 mesh silica gel. Thin-layer chromatography (TLC) analysis was performed using silica gel plates GF254 (Qindao Haiyang Chemical, China). NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker MSL-600 or MSL-300 with CDCl3, CD3OD, DMSO-d6 as the solvents and tetramethylsilane as the internal standard. Chemical shifts are expressed as δ values and coupling constants (J) are reported in hertz (Hz). Peak multiplicities are reported as the singlet (s), doublet (d), triplet (t), quadruplet (q), broad singlet (bs), and multiplet (m). The high-resolution mass spectrum (HRMS) was recorded on an API-3000 LC–MS spectrometer. The purities of the target compounds were obtained by RP-HPLC (Agilent 1260) with CH3OH/H2O (v/v, 7/3) as the mobile phase and C18 column as the stationary phase, and they are all above 95%.
    Methyl 4-(3-Cyanopropoxy)benzoate (2a)
    To a stirred solution of methyl 4-hydroxybenzoate (1a, 500 mg, 3.29 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and 4-bromobutanenitrile (730 mg, 4.93 mmol, 1.5 equiv) in DMF (20 mL), was added K2CO3 (1.36 g, 9.87 mmol, 3.0 equiv). The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. Then, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, filtered, and the filtrate was diluted with water (100 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 2). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL × 3), dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under the reduced pressure. The residue was purified via silica gel column chromatography (n-hexane/EtOAc, 10/1, v/v) to afford intermediate 2a (599 mg, 83% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.99 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.90 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 4.12 (t, J = 5.7 Hz, 2H), 3.88 (s, 3H), 2.60 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 2.21–2.09 (m, 2H).
    Methyl 4-(3-(1H-1,2,4-Triazol-3-yl)propoxy)benzoate (3a)
    To a stirred solution of intermediate 2a (500 mg, 2.28 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in anhydrous CH3OH (2 mL) was added 4 M HCl dioxane solution (15 mL). The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h, and then, diethyl ether (100 mL) was added to the mixture. The precipitated white solid was filtered and used directly in the next step. To the stirred solution of the obtained white solid in CH3OH (20 mL), formhydrazide (151 mg, 2.51 mmol, 1.1 equiv) and Et3N (461 mg, 4.56 mmol, 2.0 equiv) were added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 18 h. Then, the solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residual mixture was purified via silica gel column chromatography (CH2Cl2/CH3OH, 80/1, v/v) to afford intermediate 3a (316 mg, 53% yield) as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.05 (s, 1H), 7.97 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.87 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 4.03 (t, J = 5.9 Hz, 2H), 3.89 (s, 3H), 2.93 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.16–2.05 (m, 2H).
    Oxirane 4 was prepared according to the previous reported method.(50)
    To a stirred solution of intermediate 3a (800 mg, 3.06 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and oxirane 4 (1.12 g, 3.37 mmol, 1.1 equiv) in DMF (20 mL) was added K2CO3 (845 mg, 6.12 mmol, 2.0 equiv). The mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h, and then, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, filtered, and the filtrate was diluted with water (50 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 2). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL × 3), dried over Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. TLC analysis of the residual mixture indicated that the reaction produced two main products with similar Rf values. The residual mixture was purified via silica gel column chromatography (CH2Cl2/CH3OH, 100/1, v/v) to afford intermediate 5a (472 mg, 31% yield) and 6a (307 mg, 20% yield) as a pale yellow solid. Intermediate 5a and 6a had similar 1D-NMR, whose chemical structures were further determined by 2D-NMR (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information).
    Methyl 4-(3-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl)propoxy)benzoate (5a)
    1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.04 (s, 1H), 7.93 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.82 (s, 1H), 7.39–7.34 (m, 1H), 6.85 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.79–6.73 (m, 1H), 6.72–6.66 (m, 1H), 5.56 (s, 1H), 4.66 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.65 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.45 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.33 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.00–3.91 (m, 2H), 3.84 (s, 3H), 2.82 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.16–2.10 (m, 2H).
    Methyl 4-(3-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)propoxy)benzoate (6a)
    1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 8.11 (s, 1H), 7.97 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 7.81 (s, 1H), 7.74 (s, 1H), 7.45–7.39 (m, 1H), 6.87 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 6.78–6.75 (m, 1H), 6.74–6.70 (m, 1H), 5.82 (s, 1H), 4.71 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.67 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.58 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.23 (d, J = 14.4 Hz, 1H), 4.07–3.98 (m, 2H), 3.87 (s, 3H), 2.84 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 2.26–2.13 (m, 2H).
    4-(3-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl)propoxy)-N-hydroxybenzamide (7a)
    To a stirred solution of hydroxyl amine hydrochloride (2.30 g, 33.1 mmol) in CH3OH (20 mL) was added KOH (2.80 g, 49.9 mmol), the mixture was stirred at 0 °C for 30 min. The precipitate was filtered off and the filtrate (freshly prepared NH2OH in CH3OH) was added dropwise to a round-bottom flask containing intermediate 5a (250 mg, 0.502 mmol). The new mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5 h, followed by concentration under reduced pressure. Water (50 mL) was added to the residue and acidified to pH 7 by 1 M HCl. Then, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 3). The combined organic layers were dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure; then, the residual mixture was purified via silica gel column chromatography (CH2Cl2/CH3OH, 35/1, v/v) to afford compound 7a (198 mg, 79% yield) as a pale yellow solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 11.07 (s, 1H), 8.91 (s, 1H), 8.33 (s, 1H), 8.21 (s, 1H), 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.72 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.21–7.16 (m, 2H), 6.94 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.87–6.83 (m, 1H), 6.35 (s, 1H), 4.74 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.65 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.57 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.49 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 3.96–3.91 (m, 2H), 2.64 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 1.97–1.92 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 165.90, 164.15, 163.88 (dd, J = 246.6, 12.6 Hz), 162.62, 160.95 (dd, J = 247.2, 12.3 Hz), 152.63, 147.26, 146.95, 131.55 (dd, J = 8.7, 6.0 Hz), 130.4, 126.67, 125.36 (d, J = 12.8 Hz), 115.86, 112.66 (d, J = 20.4 Hz), 105.70 (t, J = 26.8 Hz), 75.57 (d, J = 4.6 Hz), 68.47, 56.67, 50.43, 29.04, 25.7. HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C23H24F2N7O4 [M + H]+, 500.1852; found, 500.1852.
    Compounds 7b and 7c were synthesized using the similar method described for the preparation of compound 7a.
    2-(4-(3-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl)propoxy)phenyl)-N-hydroxyacetamide (7b)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 82% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.30 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.83 (s, 1H), 7.29–7.22 (m, 1H), 7.17 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.99–6.93 (m, 1H), 6.82 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.78–6.72 (m, 1H), 4.82 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.77 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.63 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.58 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 3.92–3.83 (m, 2H), 3.33 (s, 2H), 2.78 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 2.08–2.03 (m, 2H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C24H26F2N7O4 [M + H]+, 514.2009; found, 514.1996.
    4-(4-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-3-yl)butoxy)-N-hydroxybenzamide (7c)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 73% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.35 (s, 1H), 8.23 (s, 1H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.85 (s, 1H), 7.31–7.25 (m, 1H), 7.01–6.97 (m, 1H), 6.96 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.81–6.75 (m, 1H), 4.84 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.81 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.70 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.55 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.01 (t, J = 6.2 Hz, 2H), 2.66 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H), 1.82–1.74 (m, 2H), 1.71–1.62 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, CD3OD): δ 165.23, 161.81, 161.63 (dd, J = 249.1, 12.6 Hz), 160.44, 157.92 (dd, J = 246.7, 12.0 Hz), 148.84, 143.59, 143.40, 128.07 (dd, J = 9.2, 5.6 Hz), 126.98, 122.56, 121.26 (dd, J = 13.0, 2.9 Hz), 112.46, 109.37 (d, J = 20.8 Hz), 102.18 (t, J = 27.0 Hz), 72.74 (d, J = 4.5 Hz), 65.82, 53.65, 53.45, 26.46, 25.27, 22.72. HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C24H26F2N7O4 [M + H]+, 514.2009; found, 514.2021.
    4-(3-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)propoxy)-N-hydroxybenzamide (8a)
    Compound 8a was prepared from intermediate 6a using the similar method as described for the synthesis of compound 7a from intermediate 5a. Compound 8a was obtained in 187 mg yield. Compound 8a (187 mg, 75% yield) was obtained as a pale yellow solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 11.07 (s, 1H), 8.91 (s, 1H), 8.33 (s, 1H), 7.78 (s, 1H), 7.73 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.72 (s, 1H), 7.22–7.16 (m, 2H), 6.97 (d, st J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.91–6.85 (m, 1H), 6.28 (s, 1H), 4.82 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.65 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.60 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 4.51 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 4.11–4.04 (m, 2H), 2.86–2.77 (m, 2H), 2.15–2.04 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 165.85, 163.89 (dd, J = 246.3, 12.6 Hz), 162.54, 161.02 (dd, J = 247.2, 12.3 Hz), 158.21, 152.57, 151.63, 146.92, 131.60 (dd, J = 8.1, 6.4 Hz), 130.47, 126.75, 125.56 (d, J = 10.8 Hz), 115.90, 112.71 (d, J = 20.5 Hz), 105.73 (t, J = 27.0 Hz), 76.29 (d, J = 4.6 Hz), 68.56, 56.53, 55.58, 28.25, 23.40. HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C23H24F2N7O4 [M + H]+, 500.1852; found, 500.1852.
    Compounds 8b and 8c were synthesized by the similar method described for the preparation of compound 8a.
    2-(4-(3-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)propoxy)phenyl)-N-hydroxyacetamide (8b)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 82% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.32 (s, 1H), 7.80 (s, 1H), 7.75 (s, 1H), 7.33–7.28 (m, 1H), 7.19 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.97–6.92 (m, 1H), 6.81 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.81–6.79 (m, 1H), 4.88 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 4.70 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 4.69 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.52 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 3.99–3.92 (m, 2H), 3.33 (s, 2H), 2.96–2.84 (m, 2H), 2.18–2.12 (m, 2H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C24H26F2N7O4 [M + H]+, 514.2009; found, 514.2021.
    4-(4-(1-(2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)-1H-1,2,4-triazol-5-yl)butoxy)-N-hydroxybenzamide (8c)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 84% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.35 (s, 1H), 7.94 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 7.81 (s, 1H), 7.74 (s, 1H), 7.32–7.25 (m, 1H), 7.02–6.91 (m, 1H), 6.94 (d, J = 8.9 Hz, 2H), 6.83–6.75 (m, 1H), 4.91 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 4.73 (d, J = 14.7 Hz, 1H), 4.70 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.57 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.03 (t, J = 5.9 Hz, 2H), 2.80–2.70 (m, 2H), 1.93–1.86 (m, 2H), 1.86–1.76 (m, 2H). HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C24H26F2N7O4 [M + H]+, 514.2009; found, 514.1996.
    Starting materials 9a–j and intermediate 10 were prepared according to the previous reported method.(37,48−50)
    Methyl 4-(3-Bromopropyl)benzoate (9g)
    The product was obtained as yellow liquid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.97 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 7.27 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 3.91 (s, 3H), 3.39 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 2.84 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.29–2.13 (m, 2H).
    Methyl 4-(4-Bromobutyl)benzoate (9h)
    The product was obtained as yellow liquid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.96 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 7.25 (d, J = 8.2 Hz, 2H), 3.90 (s, 3H), 3.42 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 2.70 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 1.93–1.76 (m, 4H).
    Methyl 2-(4-(3-Bromopropoxy)phenyl)acetate (9j)
    The product was obtained as colorless oil. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.23 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.89 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 4.12 (t, J = 5.8 Hz, 2H), 3.71 (s, 3H), 3.63 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 3.58 (s, 2H), 2.36–2.31 (m, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H).
    tert-Butyl Methyl(4-(5-oxo-1,5-dihydro-4H-1,2,4-triazol-4-yl)benzyl)carbamate (10)
    The product was obtained as a white solid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 10.59 (s, 1H), 7.70 (s, 1H), 7.51 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.37 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 4.45 (s, 2H), 2.81 (s, 3H), 1.48 (s, 9H).
    4-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)-N-hydroxybutanamide (12a)
    To a stirred solution of intermediate 9a (297 mg, 1.64 mmol, 1.0 equiv) and intermediate 10 (500 mg, 1.64 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in DMF (10 mL) was added K2CO3 (680 mg, 4.93 mmol, 3.0 equiv), the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 2 h. After being cooled to room temperature, the mixture was filtered, and the filtrate was diluted with water (50 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 2). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL × 3), dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residual mixture was purified via silica gel column chromatography (n-hexane/EtOAc, 5/1, v/v) to afford intermediate 11a (515 mg, 78% yield) as a white solid.1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.69 (s, 1H), 7.50 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 7.32 (d, J = 7.8 Hz, 2H), 4.43 (s, 2H), 3.91 (t, J = 6.7 Hz, 2H), 3.66 (s, 3H), 2.84 (s, 3H), 2.42 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.16–2.09 (m, 2H), 1.46 (s, 9H).
    To a stirred solution of intermediate 11a (500 mg, 1.24 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in anhydrous CH2Cl2 (5 mL) was added CF3CO2H (5 mL), the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. Then solvent was removed under reduced pressure and the residue was dissolved in DMF (10 mL). Oxirane 4 (454 mg, 1.36 mmol, 1.1 equiv) and K2CO3 (513 mg, 3.72 mmol, 3.0 equiv) were added into the solution, and the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature, filtered and the filtrate was diluted with water (50 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 2). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL × 3), dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residual mixture was added into the freshly prepared NH2OH solution in CH3OH. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5 h, and concentrated under reduced pressure. Water (50 mL) was added to the residue and acidified to pH 7 with 1 M HCl. Then, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 3). The combined organic layers were dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure; then, the residual mixture was purified via silica gel column chromatography (CH2Cl2/CH3OH, 40/1, v/v) to afford compound 12a (285 mg, 42% yield) as a pale yellow solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.29 (s, 1H), 8.16 (s, 1H), 7.74 (s, 1H), 7.57–7.52 (m, 1H), 7.51 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 7.30 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.96–6.90 (m, 1H), 6.90–6.82 (m, 1H), 4.59 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 4.56 (d, J = 14.6 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.56 (s, 2H), 3.09 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 2.88 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 2.19 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 2.15 (s, 3H), 2.12–2.07 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, CD3OD): δ 171.83, 164.20 (dd, J = 247.7, 12.2 Hz), 160.66 (dd, J = 246.2, 11.8 Hz), 153.71, 151.21, 146.14, 139.78, 136.47, 134.23, 131.17, 131.03 (dd, J = 9.1, 6.1 Hz), 127.37 (d, J = 12.7 Hz), 123.51, 112.09 (d, J = 20.8 Hz), 104.97 (t, J = 26.9 Hz), 75.15 (d, J = 5.2 Hz), 63.68, 63.13, 57.45, 45.88, 44.55, 30.78, 25.76. HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C25H29F2N8O4 [M + H]+, 543.2274; found, 543.2288.
    Compounds 12b–j were synthesized using the similar method of the preparation of 12a.
    5-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)-N-hydroxypentanamide (12b)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 47% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.27 (s, 1H), 8.13 (s, 1H), 7.72 (s, 1H), 7.55–7.49 (m, 1H), 7.48 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 7.28 (d, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 6.93–6.87 (m, 1H), 6.86–6.79 (m, 1H), 4.55 (s, 2H), 3.84 (t, J = 6.6 Hz, 2H), 3.52 (s, 2H), 3.06 (d, J = 13.9 Hz, 1H), 2.85 (d, J = 13.9 Hz, 1H), 2.14 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.12 (s, 3H), 1.85–1.74 (m, 2H), 1.72–1.61 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, CD3OD): δ 169.53, 161.27 (dd, J = 247.4, 12.4 Hz), 157.76 (dd, J = 246.3, 11.8 Hz), 150.74, 148.28, 143.22, 137.06, 133.43, 131.28, 128.22, 128.11 (d, J = 9.0 Hz), 124.51 (dd, J = 12.9, 3.2 Hz), 120.55, 109.14 (d, J = 20.8 Hz), 102.03 (t, J = 26.9 Hz), 72.32 (d, J = 5.3 Hz), 60.81, 60.37, 54.56, 43.11, 41.64, 30.21, 26.06, 20.74.     6-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)-N-hydroxyhexanamide (12c)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 49% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.31 (s, 1H), 8.17 (s, 1H), 7.74 (s, 1H), 7.55–7.51 (m, 1H), 7.50 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.29 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 6.93–6.88 (m, 1H), 6.88–6.81 (m, 1H), 4.58 (s, 2H), 3.84 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H), 3.56 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 3.53 (d, J = 13.5 Hz, 1H), 3.09 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 2.88 (d, J = 13.8 Hz, 1H), 2.11 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 1.83–1.75 (m, 2H), 1.72–1.65 (m, 2H), 1.43–1.36 (m, 2H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, CD3OD): δ 171.30, 162.75 (dd, J = 247.6, 12.3 Hz), 159.24 (dd, J = 246.5, 11.8 Hz), 152.21, 149.78, 144.71, 138.50, 134.84, 132.78, 129.71, 129.62 (dd, J = 9.2, 6.5 Hz), 125.99 (dd, J = 12.7, 3.1 Hz), 122.04, 110.64 (d, J = 20.6 Hz), 103.53 (t, J = 26.9 Hz), 73.80 (d, J = 5.3 Hz), 62.29, 61.87, 56.06 (d, J = 4.4 Hz), 44.95, 43.13, 32.17, 27.79, 25.59, 24.80. HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C27H33F2N8O4 [M + H]+, 571.2587; found, 571.2601.
    7-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)-N-hydroxyheptanamide (12d)

    4-(4-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butyl)-N-hydroxybenzamide (12h)

    2-(4-(2-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethoxy)phenyl)-N-hydroxyacetamide (12i)

    2-(4-(3-(4-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)-5-oxo-4,5-dihydro-1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propoxy)phenyl)-N-hydroxyacetamide (12j)

    Starting materials 13a–q were prepared according to the previous reported method.(46,47,49)
    Methyl 5-(4-Formylphenoxy)pentanoate (13a)
    The product is obtained as colorless liquid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.88 (s, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.98 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 4.06 (t, J = 5.9 Hz, 2H), 3.68 (s, 3H), 2.38 (t, J = 5.3 Hz, 2H), 1.93–1.70 (m, 4H).
    Methyl 6-(4-Formylphenoxy)hexanoate (13b)
    The product is obtained as colorless liquid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.88 (s, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.99 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 4.05 (t, J = 6.4 Hz, 2H), 3.68 (s, 3H), 2.32 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.93–1.62 (m, 6H).
    Methyl 7-(4-Formylphenoxy)heptanoate (13c)
    The product is obtained as colorless liquid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.88 (s, 1H), 7.83 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 6.99 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 4.04 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 3.67 (s, 3H), 2.30 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.86–1.54 (m, 8H).
    Methyl 8-(4-Formylphenoxy)octanoate (13d)
    The product is obtained as colorless liquid. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.87 (s, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 6.98 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 2H), 4.03 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 3.67 (s, 3H), 2.30 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 1.83–1.52 (m, 10H).
    Methyl 2-(4-(3-(4-Formylphenyl)propoxy)phenyl)acetate (13e)
    The product is obtained as a white solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 10.00 (s, 1H), 7.84 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.40 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.22 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.87 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 3.98 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 3.68 (s, 3H), 3.58 (s, 2H), 2.93 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 2.18–2.12 (m, 2H).
    Methyl 2-(4-(4-(4-Formylphenyl)butanamido)phenyl)acetate (13h)
    The product is obtained as a yellow solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.98 (s, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.45 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 7.37 (d, J = 8.0 Hz, 2H), 7.23 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 1H), 7.08 (s, 1H), 3.69 (s, 3H), 3.59 (s, 2H), 2.80 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 2.37 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.13–2.08 (m, 2H).
    Methyl 2-(4-(3-(4-Formylphenoxy)propoxy)phenyl)acetate (13i)
    The product is obtained as a white solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 9.89 (s, 1H), 8.00 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 7.84 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 7.02 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.93 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 2H), 4.29 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 4.25 (t, J = 6.0 Hz, 2H), 3.89 (s, 3H), 2.41–2.31 (m, 2H).
    5-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenoxy)-N-hydroxypentanamide (15a)
    To a stirred solution of methyl 5-(4-formylphenoxy)pentanoate 13a (500 mg, 2.12 mmol, 1.0 equiv), methylamine hydrochloride (214 mg, 3.17 mmol, 1.5 equiv) and Et3N (641 mg, 6.35 mmol, 3.0 equiv) in anhydrous CH3OH (20 mL) was added tetraisopropoxytitanium (1.202 g, 4.23 mmol, 2.0 equiv), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. Then, NaBH4 (640 mg, 16.9 mmol, 8.0 equiv) was added to the mixture portion wise followed by stirring at room temperature for 30 min. The reaction was quenched by the addition of water (10 mL), and the resulting precipitate was filtered. The filtrate was diluted with water (60 mL), extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 2), and the combined organic layer was dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure to afford intermediate 14a (493 mg, 93% yield) as a pale yellow oil. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CDCl3): δ 7.24 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.86 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 3.97 (t, J = 5.9 Hz, 2H), 3.70 (s, 2H), 3.69 (s, 3H), 2.45 (s, 3H), 2.41 (t, J = 7.0 Hz, 2H), 1.85–1.82 (m, 4H).
    To a stirred solution of intermediate 14a (450 mg, 1.79 mmol, 1.0 equiv) in DMF (10 mL) was added oxirane 4 (656 mg, 1.97 mmol, 1.1 equiv) and K2CO3 (741 mg, 5.37 mmol, 3.0 equiv); the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. Then, the mixture was cooled to room temperature, filtered, and the filtrate was diluted with water (50 mL) and extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 2). The combined organic layers were washed with brine (50 mL × 3), dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residual mixture was added into the freshly prepared NH2OH in CH3OH. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 5 h and concentrated under reduced pressure. Water (50 mL) was added to the residue and acidified to pH 7 with 1 M HCl. Then, the mixture was extracted with EtOAc (50 mL × 3), and the combined organic layers were dried with Na2SO4, filtered, and concentrated under reduced pressure. The residual mixture was purified via silica gel column chromatography (CH2Cl2/CH3OH, 40/1, v/v) to afford compound 15a (371 mg, 42% yield) as a pale yellow solid. 1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 10.37 (s, 1H), 8.70 (s, 1H), 8.28 (s, 1H), 7.73 (s, 1H), 7.44–7.39 (m, 1H), 7.17–7.10 (m, 1H), 6.98 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 6.97–6.93 (m, 1H), 6.78 (d, J = 8.7 Hz, 2H), 5.70 (s, 1H), 4.53 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 4.48 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 3.91 (t, J = 6.1 Hz, 2H), 3.44 (d, J = 13.0 Hz, 1H), 3.32 (d, J = 13.0 Hz, 1H), 2.96 (d, J = 13.7 Hz, 1H), 2.74 (d, J = 13.7 Hz, 1H), 2.04 (s, 3H), 2.00 (t, J = 7.1 Hz, 2H), 1.70–1.60 (m, 4H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 169.39, 162.11 (dd, J = 245.5, 12.4 Hz), 159.38 (dd, J = 246.8, 12.1 Hz), 158.06, 150.88, 145.33, 131.07, 130.30, 130.29, 126.71 (d, J = 10.3 Hz), 114.42, 111.09 (d, J = 20.8 Hz), 104.16 (t, J = 26.8 Hz), 75.35 (d, J = 5.3 Hz), 67.41, 63.21, 62.52, 56.32, 43.90, 32.37, 28.68, 22.26. HRMS (ESI) m/z: calcd for C24H30F2N5O4 [M + H]+, 490.2260; found, 490.2264.
    Compounds 15b–t were synthesized by the similar method described for the preparation of 15a.
    6-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenoxy)-N-hydroxyhexanamide (15b)

    7-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenoxy)-N-hydroxyheptanamide (15c)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 38% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, CD3OD): δ 8.31 (s, 1H), 7.74 (s, 1H), 7.56–7.49 (m, 1H), 7.06 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 6.93–6.88 (m, 1H), 6.87–6.83 (m, 1H), 6.80 (d, J = 8.5 Hz, 2H), 4.56 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 4.53 (d, J = 14.5 Hz, 1H), 3.94 (t, J = 6.3 Hz, 2H), 3.44 (d, J = 12.8 Hz, 1H), 3.39 (d, J = 14.2 Hz, 1H), 3.02 (d, J = 13.9 Hz, 1H), 2.90 (d, J = 13.7 Hz, 1H), 2.15 (t, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 2.11 (s, 3H), 1.83–1.74 (m, 2H), 1.74–1.66 (m, 2H), 1.56–1.47 (m, 2H).     8-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenoxy)-N-hydroxyoctanamide (15d)
    The product was obtained as a pale yellow solid in 38% yield. 1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d6): δ 10.30 (s, 1H), 8.63 (s, 1H), 8.26 (s, 1H), 7.71 (s, 1H), 7.42–7.36 (m, 1H), 7.14–7.09 (m, 1H), 6.96 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 6.95–6.89 (m, 1H), 6.76 (d, J = 8.4 Hz, 2H), 5.67 (s, 1H), 4.51 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 4.46 (d, J = 14.3 Hz, 1H), 3.88 (t, J = 6.5 Hz, 2H), 3.42 (d, J = 13.1 Hz, 1H), 3.28 (J = 13.1 Hz, 1H), 2.94 (d, J = 13.6 Hz, 1H), 2.72 (d, J = 13.6 Hz, 1H), 2.02 (s, 3H), 1.92 (t, J = 7.3 Hz, 2H), 1.69–1.63 (m, 2H), 1.49–1.44 (m, 2H), 1.37–1.21 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (151 MHz, CD3OD): δ 171.56, 162.69 (dd, J = 247.7, 12.2 Hz), 159.20 (dd, J = 246.3, 12.1 Hz), 158.46, 149.71, 144.68, 130.09, 129.97, 129.55 (dd, J = 8.8, 6.2 Hz), 126.16 (dd, J = 12.8, 3.0 Hz), 113.98, 110.64 (d, J = 20.8 Hz), 103.54 (t, J = 26.8 Hz), 73.25 (d, J = 5.4 Hz), 67.56, 62.43, 61.55, 56.22, 43.10, 32.40, 28.96, 28.72, 28.70, 25.63, 25.30.     2-(4-(3-(4-(((2-(2,4-Difluorophenyl)-2-hydroxy-3-(1H-1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)propyl)(methyl)amino)methyl)phenyl)propoxy)phenyl)-N-hydroxyacetamide (15e)

    Strains, Culture and Agents

    C. albicans SC5314, C. neoformans H99, azole-resistant C. albicans (strains number: 0304103, 4108 and 7781), and azole-resistant C. tropicalis (strains number: 5008) were provided by Changzheng Hospital of Shanghai. They were incubated in yeast extract peptone dextrose (YPD) medium (1% yeast extract, 2% peptone and 2% dextrose) at 30 °C in a shaking (200 rpm/min) incubator. Tested compounds, FLC, ITC, VOR, and SAHA were dissolved in DMSO at 6.4 mg/mL as stock solution.

    MIC80 Determination

    The MIC80 values were determined using the serial dilution method according to CLSI (M27-A3). Briefly, fungal cells were harvested during the exponential growth phase and diluted to 1 × 103 cfu/mL with RPMI 1640 medium. Two-fold serial dilutions of the tested compounds prepared from stock solution were added to the fungal dilution in 96-well plates with maximum compound concentration at 64 μg/mL. The plates inoculated with Candida cells were incubated at 35 °C for 48 h, while those inoculated with C. neoformans H99 were incubated at 35 °C for 72 h. Then, the density of fungal cells in each well was detected by measuring the optical density (OD) at 630 nm with a spectrophotometer, and the inhibitory effect was calculated. Each compound was tested in triplicate.

    Sterol Composition Analysis

    A single colony of azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 was picked to inoculate into 1 mL of YPD and incubated at 30 °C for 16 h; then, 50 μL of C. albicans cells culture was used to inoculate 50 mL of YPD. Meanwhile, compound 12h (0.5 μg/mL), compound 15j (0.5 μg/mL), FLC (0.5 μg/mL), or blank control was added into the culture to treat the C. albicans cells. After the cultures were incubated at 35 °C for 24 h, the C. albicans cells were harvested by centrifugation and saponified by 10 mL of 20% NaOH (w/v) in 90% ethanol at 80 °C for 60 min. Then, 10 mL of n-hexane was added to the saponification mixture to extract sterol. Then, the solvent were evaporated under reduced pressure, and the residue was dissolved by 1 mL of cyclohexane as the GC–MS sample. Finally, GC–MS was conducted to analysis the sterol composition of each group.

    Whole Fungal Cell HDAC Enzymatic Assay

    The whole fungal cell HDAC enzymatic assay was performed according to the previously reported methods with further optimizations.(69,70) In detail, a single colony of azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 was picked to inoculate into 10 mL of YPD and incubated at 30 °C for 16 h; then, the fungal cells were harvested by centrifugation. Protoplasts of the harvested cells were prepared using 60 mg of snailase and 24 μL of 2-mercaptoethanol as fungal cell wall lyase in the 6 mL of snailase reaction buffer according to the protocol from the manufacture (Rapid Yeast Genomic DNA Isolation Kit, Sangon Biotech, China). The protoplasts were harvested by centrifugation (3000 rpm) for 5 min and resuspended by 20 mL of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Then, 100 μL of protoplasts in PBS per well was added into 96-well transparent plates and treated with different concentrations of compound 12h, 15j, SAHA, and FLC at 35 °C for 12 h. Then, 10 μL of 330 μM HDAC substrate Boc-Lys(Ac)-AMC was added to each well and incubated at 37 °C for 4 h. Stop solution (100 μL) (2 mg/mL trypsin, 1% NP 40, 10 μM SAHA, 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH = 8), 137 mM NaCl, 2.7 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl2) were added to each well with a following incubation at 37 °C for 3 h. Finally, 100 μL of mixture of each well was transferred to a 96-well black plate correspondingly, and the fluorescence intensity of each well was measured on a fluorimeter with an excitation wavelength of 360 nm and an emission wavelength of 460 nm. Experiments were performed in triplicate.

    Whole Human Cell HDAC Enzymatic Assay

    The whole human cell HDAC enzymatic assay was performed according to the previously reported method with a few modifications.(71) First, HUVEC cells were seeded into 96-well transparent plates (15,000 cells per well). After being adhered to the plate at 37 °C with 5% CO2 atmosphere for 24 h, they were treated with two-fold serial dilutions of the tested compounds for 12 h. Then, 10 μL of 3.3 mM HDAC substrate Boc-Lys(Ac)-AMC was added to each well and incubated at 37 °C for 4 h. Stop solution (100 μL) (2 mg/mL trypsin, 1% NP 40, 10 μM SAHA, 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH = 8), 137 mM NaCl, 2.7 mM KCl, 1 mM MgCl2) were added to each well with a following incubation at 37 °C for 3 h. Finally, 100 μL of mixture of each well was transferred to a 96-well black plate correspondingly, and the fluorescence intensity of each well was measured on a fluorimeter with an excitation wavelength of 360 nm and an emission wavelength of 460 nm. Experiments were performed in triplicate.

    Real-Time RT-PCR Analysis

    Azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 that were harvested during the exponential growth phase were used to inoculate 10 mL of YPD. After the evaluation of different concentrations, 32 μg/mL was used because significant difference of genes could be observed without inhibiting C. albicans cells too strongly. Then, compound 12h (32 μg/mL), 15j (32 μg/mL), FLC (32 μg/mL), or blank control were added into the culture to treated the C. albicans cells. After the cultures were incubated at 35 °C for 16 h, total RNA of each group was isolated according to the manufacture’s protocol (Column Fungal RNAOUT, Tiandz, China), and cDNA was obtained using a RT kit (Takara Biotechnology, China). Real-time RT-PCR was performed on a LightCycler real-time PCR system (Roche Diagnostics GmbH Mannheim, Germany) using SYBR Green I as the fluorescence indicator. The experimental procedure was performed with 40 cycles. The fluorescence change of SYBR Green I was monitored during the each cycle to measure the threshold cycle (CT). ACT1 was used as an internal control gene. Compared with ACT1, relative fold change of the gene expression levels for each group were calculated using the formula 2(−ΔΔCT). Real-time PCR reaction for each cDNA was performed in triplicate. The primers used in the assay are shown in Table S2 in the Supporting Information.

    Rh6G Efflux Assay

    Azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 that were harvested during the exponential growth phase were inoculated into 8 mL of YPD. Then, compound 12h (32 μg/mL), 15j (32 μg/mL), FLC (32 μg/mL), or blank control was added into the culture to treat the C. albicans cells. After the cultures were incubated at 35 °C for 16 h, C. albicans cells were harvested and diluted to OD at 630 nm to 0.5 (OD630 = 0.5) with PBS (5 mL). Then, they were incubated at 35 °C for 2 h and Rh6G was added with final concentration of 10 μM. After further incubation at 35 °C for 30 min, d-glucose was added to each group with a final concentration of 2 mM. Then, at designated time points (0, 20, 40, and 60 min), the fluorescence intensity of the supernatant (100 μL) of each group was measured on a fluorimeter with an excitation wavelength of 515 nm and an emission wavelength of 535 nm to determine the amount of extracellular Rh6G. The fluorescence intensity of each time point was measured in triplicate.

    Filamentation Assay

    The in vitro filamentation formation assay of compounds 12h, 15j, and FLC against the azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 were performed according to the previously reported methods with a few modifications.(72) Briefly, 2 mL of fungal cells suspension (1 × 105 cfu/mL) in Spider medium was inoculated into 12-well plates, and then, different concentrations of compound were added. The plates were incubated at 37 °C for 4 h. Finally, the morphology of fungal cells in each well was recorded on an Axio observer D1-inverted microscope (Carl Zeiss, Inc., Thornwood, NY) equipped for photography.

    Biofilm Formation Assay

    The in vitro biofilm formation assay of compounds 12h, 15j, and FLC against the azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 were performed according to the previously reported protocols.(73) Briefly, 100 μL of cell suspensions (1 × 106 cfu/mL) in RPMI 1640 medium was inoculated into the 96-well tissue culture plate, and the cells were cultured statically at 37 °C for 90 min. Then, the spent medium was aspirated, and each well was carefully washed three times with sterile PBS. Different concentrations of compound in RPMI 1640 medium were added, and the plates were further incubated at 37 °C for 24 h; finally, a semiquantitative biofilms formation rate was calculated using the XTT reduction assay. The experiment was performed in triplicate.

    In Vivo Antifungal Potency

    ICR female mice (4 to 6 weeks old and weighing 20–25 g) obtained from Shanghai Experimental Animal Center were fed as the experimental animals. Also, the mice were treated according to ACS guidelines on Animal Studies. Compound solution of 12h (20 mg/kg, suspended in saline with 1.5% glycerin and 0.5% Tween 80) and 15j (20 mg/kg, suspended in saline with 1.5% glycerin and 0.5% Tween 80) were freshly prepared before injection. The IC model was established by IP injection with a 0.2 mL of cyclophosphamide (100 mg/kg in saline) on day −1 and infected with a 0.2 mL inoculum (1 × 105 cfu) of azole-resistant C. albicans 0304103 by intravenous route on day 0. After 24 h, all the infectious mice were divided into six groups with four mice used for each group, and treated with saline (IP), compound 12h (IP), compound 15j (IP), saline (PO), compound 12h (PO), and compound 15j (PO), respectively, once a day for 5 days. On day 6, all the mice were euthanized and dissected, whose kidney were picked and weighed. Then, their left kidneys were homogenized in saline (1 mL), and the homogenates were diluted with saline to different concentration. The diluent homogenates were inoculated on Sabouraud’s dextrose agar medium containing a chloromycetin (100 μg/mL) plate, followed by incubation at 35 °C for 48 h. The number of colonies on each medium plate was counted to calculate the number of cfu/g of the kidney tissue and the numbers were transformed into log10 units. The differences among the groups were analyzed by Student’s t-test. Their right kidneys were stained by PAS for histological studies.

    In Vivo Survival Time Assays

    The establishments of C. albicans infectious mice were similar to the fungal burden assays. Thirty mice were randomly and equally divided into three groups (compound 12h group, compound 15j group and saline group). Compound or saline were injected IP at the dose of 20 mg/kg per day for five days. The survival time of every mice were recorded for the plotting of the survive curve. The differences between groups were analyzed using the log-rank test.

    This article references 73 other publications.

    1. 1
      Miceli, M. H.; Díaz, J. A.; Lee, S. A. Emerging opportunistic yeast infections. Lancet Infect. Dis. 2011, 11, 142– 151,  DOI: 10.1016/s1473-3099(10)70218-8
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Emerging opportunistic yeast infections
      Miceli Marisa H; Diaz Jose A; Lee Samuel A
      The Lancet. Infectious diseases (2011), 11 (2), 142-51 ISSN:.
      A growing population of immunosuppressed patients has resulted in increasingly frequent diagnoses of invasive fungal infections, including those caused by unusual yeasts. The incidence of non-albicans species of Candida is increasing compared with that of Candida albicans, and several species, such as Candida glabrata and Candida krusei, may be resistant to azole antifungal therapy. Trichosporon species are the second most common cause of fungaemia in patients with haematological malignant disease and are characterised by resistance to amphotericin and echinocandins and poor prognosis. Rhodotorula species belong to the family Cryptococcaceae, and are a cause of catheter-related fungaemia, sepsis, and invasive disease in severely immunosuppressed patients. An increasing number of sporadic cases of invasive fungal infections by non-neoformans cryptococci have been reported in immunocompromised hosts, especially for patients with advanced HIV infection or cancer who are undergoing transplant. Other uncommon yeasts that can cause invasive disease in severely immunosuppressed patients include Geotrichum, Hansenula, Malassezia, and Saccharomyces. Host immune status is a crucial determinant of the type of invasive fungal infection a patient is at risk for. Diagnosis can be challenging and relies heavily on traditional cultures of blood and other sterile sites, although serum (1,3)-β-D-glucan testing might have an adjunctive role. Although rare yeasts are emerging as opportunistic human pathogens, diagnosis remains challenging and treatment suboptimal.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC3M7kvFKhuw%253D%253D&md5=3a92de401da3daf5656338ad744bb102

      Brown, G. D.; Denning, D. W.; Levitz, S. M. Tackling human fungal infections. Science 2012, 336, 647,  DOI: 10.1126/science.1222236
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Tackling human fungal infections
      Brown, Gordon D.; Denning, David W.; Levitz, Stuart M.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2012), 336 (6082), 647CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      There is no expanded citation for this reference.

    3. 3
      Liu, N.; Tu, J.; Dong, G.; Wang, Y.; Sheng, C. Emerging new targets for the treatment of resistant fungal infections. J. Med. Chem. 2018, 61, 5484– 5511,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.7b01413
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      Emerging New Targets for the Treatment of Resistant Fungal Infections
      Liu, Na; Tu, Jie; Dong, Guoqiang; Wang, Yan; Sheng, Chunquan
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2018), 61 (13), 5484-5511CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. With the increasing morbidity and mortality of invasive fungal infections and the emergence of severe antifungal drug resistance, new drug targets and novel antifungal agents are urgently needed. Recently, better understanding of fungal pathogenesis has contributed to the rapid emergence of potential antifungal drug targets. This perspective aims to provide a comprehensive review of new antifungal targets and of medicinal chem. efforts toward inhibitor discovery. Particular focus will be placed on the druggability of the targets and their potential to treat resistant fungal infections. Innovative strategies for the next generation of antifungal therapy, such as virulence factors, protein-protein interactions, and immune response-based proteins, will also be highlighted.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvVWlsA%253D%253D&md5=ff2bf0c214005c9be04e3dfd8480d8da
    4. 4
      Fisher, M. C.; Hawkins, N. J.; Sanglard, D.; Gurr, S. J. Worldwide emergence of resistance to antifungal drugs challenges human health and food security. Science 2018, 360, 739– 742,  DOI: 10.1126/science.aap7999
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      Worldwide emergence of resistance to antifungal drugs challenges human health and food security
      Fisher, Matthew C.; Hawkins, Nichola J.; Sanglard, Dominique; Gurr, Sarah J.
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2018), 360 (6390), 739-742CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The recent rate of emergence of pathogenic fungi that are resistant to the limited no. of commonly used antifungal agents is unprecedented. The azoles, for example, are used not only for human and animal health care and crop protection but also in antifouling coatings and timber preservation. The ubiquity and multiple uses of azoles have hastened the independent evolution of resistance in many environments. One consequence is an increasing risk in human health care from naturally occurring opportunistic fungal pathogens that have acquired resistance to this broad class of chems. To avoid a global collapse in our ability to control fungal infections and to avoid crit. failures in medicine and food security, we must improve our stewardship of extant chems., promote new antifungal discovery, and leverage emerging technologies for alternative solns.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpsVCgsbg%253D&md5=8add9de472138d5aca677fa3585ddd72
    5. 5
      Perfect, J. R. The antifungal pipeline: a reality check. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2017, 16, 603– 616,  DOI: 10.1038/nrd.2017.46
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      The antifungal pipeline: a reality check
      Perfect, John R.
      Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2017), 16 (9), 603-616CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Invasive fungal infections continue to appear in record nos. as the immunocompromised population of the world increases, owing partially to the increased no. of individuals who are infected with HIV and partially to the successful treatment of serious underlying diseases. The effectiveness of current antifungal therapies - polyenes, flucytosine, azoles and echinocandins (as monotherapies or in combinations for prophylaxis, or as empiric, pre-emptive or specific therapies) - in the management of these infections has plateaued. Although these drugs are clin. useful, they have several limitations, such as off-target toxicity, and drug-resistant fungi are now emerging. New antifungals are therefore needed. In this Review, I discuss the robust and dynamic antifungal pipeline, including results from preclin. academic efforts through to pharmaceutical industry products, and describe the targets, strategies, compds. and potential outcomes.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXns1Kisrs%253D&md5=1c6fcc06db9dd97c562c0f17b1441c8d
    6. 6
      Brown, G. D.; Denning, D. W.; Gow, N. A. R.; Levitz, S. M.; Netea, M. G.; White, T. C. Hidden killers: human fungal infections. Sci. Transl. Med. 2012, 4, 165rv13,  DOI: 10.1126/scitranslmed.3004404
      [Crossref], [PubMed], Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    7. 7
      Lien, M.-Y.; Chou, C.-H.; Lin, C.-C.; Bai, L.-Y.; Chiu, C.-F.; Yeh, S.-P.; Ho, M.-W. Epidemiology and risk factors for invasive fungal infections during induction chemotherapy for newly diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia: A retrospective cohort study. PLoS One 2018, 13, e0197851  DOI: 10.1371/journal.pone.0197851
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Epidemiology and risk factors for invasive fungal infections during induction chemotherapy for newly diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia: a retrospective cohort study
      Lien, Ming-Yu; Chou, Chia-Hui; Lin, Ching-Chan; Bai, Li-Yuan; Chiu, Chang-Fang; Yeh, Su-Peng; Ho, Mao-Wang
      PLoS One (2018), 13 (6), e0197851/1-e0197851/11CODEN: POLNCL; ISSN:1932-6203. (Public Library of Science)
      This study investigated the epidemiol. and risk factors assocd. with invasive fungal infections (IFIs) during induction chemotherapy in a cohort of Taiwanese patients with newly-diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia (AML). IFIs are a significant complication in the management of immunocompromised cancer patients; such infections are assocd. with a high incidence of morbidity and mortality, particularly in many South-Asian countries, where IFI rates are increasing. We retrospectively analyzed IFI incidence data from 105 patients with newly diagnosed AML at a single center undergoing their first course of induction chemotherapy without primary antifungal prophylaxis between Nov. 2008 and Dec. 2014. Of 21 cases documented as proven/provable IFIs 16 (76%) were invasive aspergillosis, 2 (10%) were mucormycosis infections, and 3 (14%) were proven yeast infections. The lung was the most commonly affected site (n = 16; 76%); 2 patients (10%) developed fungal sinusitis. IFI cases were more often males (P = 0.020). In multivariate anal., patients with neutropenia lasting >30 days were more than twice as likely to develop IFI (OR, 2.24 [95% CI, 2.81-31.11], P<0.001). We also confirmed patients with smoker and receiving parenteral nutrition during chemotherapy were significant assocd. with IFIs. Our findings suggest that antifungal prophylaxis should be considered for patients with AML during induction chemotherapy, particularly in patients from Southeastern Asia, an area of potentially high IFI rates. We recommend that clinicians det. which patients receiving induction chemotherapy for AML are at high risk of developing IFI, to allow for targeted therapeutic prophylaxis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXhvVOmsr7K&md5=162afec989576580df80dcc6e78544ab
    8. 8
      Enoch, D. A.; Yang, H.; Aliyu, S. H.; Micallef, C. The changing epidemiology of invasive fungal infections. Methods Mol. Biol. 2017, 1508, 17– 65,  DOI: 10.1007/978-1-4939-6515-1_2
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      The changing epidemiology of invasive fungal infections
      Enoch, David A.; Yang, Huina; Aliyu, Sani H.; Micallef, Christianne
      Methods in Molecular Biology (New York, NY, United States) (2017), 1508 (Human Fungal Pathogen Identification), 17-65CODEN: MMBIED; ISSN:1940-6029. (Springer)
      Invasive fungal infections (IFI) are an emerging problem worldwide with invasive candidiasis and candidemia responsible for the majority of cases. This is predominantly driven by the widespread adoption of aggressive immunosuppressive therapy among certain patient populations (e.g., chemotherapy, transplants) and the increasing use of invasive devices such as central venous catheters (CVCs). The use of new immune modifying drugs has also opened up an entirely new spectrum of patients at risk of IFIs. While the epidemiol. of candida infections has changed in the last decade, with a gradual shift from C. albicans to non-albicans candida (NAC) strains which may be less susceptible to azoles, these changes vary between hospitals and regions depending on the type of population risk factors and antifungal use. In certain parts of the world, the incidence of IFI is strongly linked to the prevalence of other disease conditions and the ecol. niche for the organism; for instance cryptococcal and pneumocystis infections are particularly common in areas with a high prevalence of HIV disease. Poorly controlled diabetes is a major risk factor for invasive mold infections. Environmental factors and trauma also play a unique role in the epidemiol. of mold infections, with well-described hospital outbreaks linked to the use of contaminated instruments and devices. Blastomycosis is assocd. with occupational exposure (e.g., forest rangers) and recreational activities (e.g., camping and fishing). The true burden of IFI is probably an underestimate because of the absence of reliable diagnostics and lack of universal application. For example, the sensitivity of most blood culture systems for detecting candida is typically 50 %. The advent of new technol. including mol. techniques such as 18S rRNA PCR and genome sequencing is leading to an improved understanding of the epidemiol. of the less common mold and dimorphic fungal infections. Mol. techniques are also providing a platform for improved diagnosis and management of IFI. Many factors affect mortality in IFI, not least the underlying medical condition, choice of therapy, and the ability to achieve early source control. For instance, mortality due to pneumocystis pneumonia in HIV-seroneg. individuals is now higher than in seropos. patients. Of significant concern is the progressive increase in resistance to azoles and echinocandins among candida isolates, which appears to worsen the already significant mortality assocd. with invasive candidiasis. Mortality with mold infections approaches 50 % in most studies and varies depending on the site, underlying disease and the use of antifungal agents such as echinocandins and voriconazole. Nevertheless, mortality for most IFIs has generally fallen with advances in medical technol., improved care of CVCs, improved diagnostics, and more effective preemptive therapy and prophylaxis.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXktFOqtL0%253D&md5=f6e93ef28407981b84ce13bdbee5c4a8
    9. 9
      Cowen, L. E. The evolution of fungal drug resistance: modulating the trajectory from genotype to phenotype. Nat. Rev. Microbiol. 2008, 6, 187– 198,  DOI: 10.1038/nrmicro1835
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      9
      The evolution of fungal drug resistance: modulating the trajectory from genotype to phenotype
      Cowen, Leah E.
      Nature Reviews Microbiology (2008), 6 (3), 187-198CODEN: NRMACK; ISSN:1740-1526. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. Leah Cowen reviews the mechanisms that potentiate the evolution of fungal drug resistance, with an emphasis on the central role of the mol. chaperone heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) in altering the relationship between genotype and phenotype in an environmentally contingent manner, which thereby 'sculpts' the course of evolution. The emergence of drug resistance in pathogenic microorganisms provides an excellent example of microbial evolution that has had profound consequences for human health. The widespread use of antimicrobial agents in medicine and agriculture exerts strong selection for the evolution of drug resistance. Selection acts on the phenotypic consequences of resistance mutations, which are influenced by the genetic variation in particular genomes. Recent studies have revealed a mechanism by which the mol. chaperone heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) can alter the relationship between genotype and phenotype in an environmentally contingent manner, thereby 'sculpting' the course of evolution. Harnessing Hsp90 holds great promise for treating life-threatening infectious diseases.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXhvFCgt7k%253D&md5=e55ad31b236ffc2ea0a9aa427b53b006
    10. 10
      McCarthy, M. W.; Kontoyiannis, D. P.; Cornely, O. A.; Perfect, J. R.; Walsh, T. J. Novel agents and drug targets to meet the challenges of resistant fungi. J. Infect. Dis. 2017, 216, S474– S483,  DOI: 10.1093/infdis/jix130
